author: Mark O'Hara
title: Must Read: How Does General Motors’ Future Look? - Yahoo Finance
text:
Key Takeaways from General Motors’ Global Business Conference 
Continual change The ever-changing automobile industry has come a long way since Ford (F) launched its revolutionary Model T in 1908. Since then, the automotive industry has never stopped innovating.
During the last two decades, the automotive industry has experienced significant churn. First, Toyota Motors (TM) took as over the leading automaker from General Motors (GM). However, the largest automobile company is Germany-based Volkswagen (VLKAY). Together, General Motors and Ford (F) form ~4.4% of the Consumer Discretionary Select Sector SPDR ETF (XLY).

Fresh competition In the last few years, while car manufacturers were fighting for a share of global car sales, disruptive technology began to build. Many analysts view Apple and Uber as future competitors of the automobile industry.
The lead industry disruptor is Tesla Motors (TSLA), which is racing ahead with its electric vehicles. At current stock prices, Tesla is valued 60% higher than Fiat Chrysler (FCAU). Tesla has outperformed mainstream automakers by a wide margin, as shown in the above chart.
Series overview The automotive industry finds itself at a crossroads. Self-driving cars, car sharing, and electric vehicles have made leading industry players rethink their business plans. Investors need to keep track of how auto companies are steeling themselves against this onslaught of disruptive technology.
Company conference calls often throw light on a company’s business strategy. In this series, we’ll look at the key takeaways from General Motors’ global business conference, which was held on October 1, 2015.
Continue to Next Part
